description.plain:
Prom Queen is the title song from Beach Bunny’s EP “Prom Queen”. The song was initially released in 2018, but rose to popularity from the popular video app TikTok in 2020.

The song itself is the inner monologue of a girl struggling to accept herself for who she is; it follows the girl as she changes herself to fit the societal ideal of beauty.

The message of this song is to remind the listener (who is most likely a young woman, seeing as Beach Bunny’s genre is self-proclaimed “sad-girl” music) to not change themselves to get people to like them and to learn to be happy with who they are on the inside, because the relationships they form from being beautifully, uniquely, and totally herself will be more rewarding and they will feel more “okay”.

song.embed_content: Read “Prom Queen” by Beach Bunny on Genius
song.title: Prom Queen

annotations: There’s plastic wrap in my cheeks

When you’re bulimic, the stomach acid from vomiting can affect your cheeks, making them puffy and making you look more overweight, thus having the opposite of the intended effect. Having plastic wrap in your cheeks is likely a trick used to stop the stomach acid from touching your cheeks, thus preventing the puffiness. It should be noted however that it’ll do nothing to stop the stomach acid form harming your teeth and esophagus.
I’m a defect surgical project

She is constantly finding more and more faults to be insecure about, things that she feels the need to “fix”. Hence, she feels like an on-going and faulty (“defect”) project.

This could also be a reference to plastic surgery; she keeps getting cosmetic fixes, but in her eyes it isn’t enough – her lack of “natural beauty” by society’s standards is impossible to fix.
Shut up, count your calories
Calorie-counting (and consequently, calorie-restricting) is a method of weight loss. She feels the need to be thinner in order to feel beautiful.

I’ve been starving myself, carving
 Skin until my bones are showing

CW: eating disorders

This is an allusion to eating disorders (EDs). As of 2020, 8% of American women, or approximately 1 in 12, will have an ED in their lifetime, and about 1 in 3 experience symptoms of one or EDs. The most common of these is anorexia nervosa, in which the sufferer experiences obsessive-compulsive tendencies around their weight, eats very little and infrequently, and often categorizes certain kinds of food as unsafe, dangerous, or unhealthy and avoids eating them.

This high occurrence has been linked to societal commandments around women’s bodies, and especially that that women be as thin as possible.  This song is about body image and beauty standards for young women, and here, Beach Bunny allude to one of the most dangerous outcomes of these expectations by describing a character who literally diets until she is visibly malnourished, which is to say, has an eating disorder.

They say beauty is pain
 You’ll only be happy
 If you look a certain way

Girls and women usually put more time and effort into their appearance, thus the meaning of “Beauty is pain”. The singer, possibly judging by the people around her, thinks that if you’re not as good looking as others, then you’ll never be happy.
It’s getting hard to breathe
She clearly suffers from self-esteem issues, anxiety and she may have panic attacks since she thinks people may stare at her and judge her, which is a big fear she clearly has.

Maybe I should try harder
 You should lower your expectations
The singer is having a hard time figuring out if she should put more effort in her body or if people need to accept her for her and be less judgmental.

Wish I was like you
 Blue-eyed blondie, perfect body

Girls with blue eyes and blonde hair are usually the pretty, popular girls in some high school movies. They could also the main protagonists of any kind of movie. Girls with blue eyes and blonde are said to very desirable and because of this, the singer wishes she was like that instead of noticing her own natural beauty.



Lili Trifilio, the lead singer of Beach Bunny, has confirmed that this song is for people who suffer from self-esteem, depression, etc. She didn’t write the song because she suffers from these issues.
I never look good in mom jeans
“Mom Jeans” are a style of denim trouser popularised in the late 2010s. The style’s characteristics mainly include a high waistline and slightly baggy areas in the leg and crotch areas.
I’m no Quick-Curl Barbie
Quick Curl Barbie is a vintage Barbie doll from the 1970’s. The term quick curl came from the iconic ‘70s hairstyle, a popular style among women during that decade.

description.plain:
“Cloud 9” is track nine on Beach Bunny’s debut album Honeymoon. It was released on January 10, 2020 as the album’s third single.

This is a giddy love song about an uplifting love interest. It describes the highs and initial euphoria of a relationship.

“Cloud 9” went viral on the social media platform TikTok as of March 2021. It charted in the US, Canada, Ireland, and the UK. It peaked at #9 on Billboard’s Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles and #12 on Billboard’s Hot Rock & Alternative Songs. The success of the song ultimately led to a remix of the track featuring Tegan and Sara.

description.plain: Sports is about being unsure in a relationship with another person. The singer wants to pursue a relationship with a love interest that seems ambivalent and unsure about what they want. This leads the singer to be frustrated and confused about the relationship. Beach Bunny presents a relatable juxtaposition between sports and love while she laments over being forced to play “games”–something that has exhausted her in life.

body.plain: Sports is about being unsure in a relationship with another person. The singer wants to pursue a relationship with a love interest that seems ambivalent and unsure about what they want. This leads the singer to be frustrated and confused about the relationship. Beach Bunny presents a relatable juxtaposition between sports and love while she laments over being forced to play “games”–something that has exhausted her in life.

annotations:
It always feels like
 I need more
 Jesus Christ, you’re so confusing

She feels like she is the only one pursuing the relationship due to her partner’s half-assed attempts at making it work out, and how confusing the partner is due to them never communicating how they feel about it.
Love’s a word I’ve always hated
She hates the word “Love"

I’m tired of waitin’
 I was never good at sports
This could be her saying that she was never good at dealing with the situations that her lover is constantly putting her through. It’s getting frustrating and she’s lost her patience.

Why are we so complicated?
 Maybe love is overrated

She and her lover may be so different and they may end up acting in ways that emotionally hurt or confuse the other. Because of this, the singer may think that love is literally overrated and just not worth it.

If you feel broken
 Promise I won’t break your heart
 If you shatter
 I won’t let you fall apart
She’s essentially saying she’ll do anything for him. If he’s feeling broken she won’t hurt him. If he is about to breakdown she’ll be there for him and will keep him from falling apart

If we keep score
 Bet my money that I’m losing
She knows being in this relationship isn’t benefitting her. Her partners always getting what he wants out of the relationship but she’s not getting what she wants.

Say you need me
 But lately, you feel unsure
 Come on to me, come on to me
 I need more
Bunny’s love interest still isn’t sure whether or not they want to be with her. But she needs more than their ambivalent responses because she is putting a lot more effort into their relationship.

If you feel lonely
 I could be lonely with you
 Tell me, baby
 Why do you seem so blue?
Bunny addresses the loneliness and sadness her love interest feels and wants to make them feel better, presumably by being in a relationship and offering companionship.
Save the games for the girls on the tennis court

Here bunny is talking about relationships/significant others playing ‘games’, or messing around with her head. She says to save them for the girls on the tennis court, as the ‘games’ is also referring to the sport tennis. Instead of playing mind-games on her whilst in this toxic relationship, save the games for a situation in a tennis court.

description.plain:
“Good Girls (Don’t Get Used)” is the lead single from Beach Bunny’s fifth EP Blame Game, described by songwriter Lili Trifilio as a “sassy song that calls out players by talking down to them as if they were children, showing that poor communication skills and mind games are immature”. The song serves as an introduction to the EP’s more angsty and confident themes compared to Beach Bunny’s preceding Honeymoon album, which was described by Trifilio as a “breakup album” with more sad lyrical themes.

The band teased the single by releasing a racing game on their website called “The Blame Game” (which would later be revealed as the title of the EP). The goal of the game was to collect six items scattered across the map. Once the player beat the game, they were taken to a link to pre-save the song on Spotify. The game featured an 8-bit rendition of the single as its background music, which players could also download once they completed the game.

The song serves as an introduction to the EP’s more angsty and confident themes compared to Beach Bunny’s preceding Honeymoon album, which was described by Trifilio as a “breakup album” with more sad lyrical themes.

The band teased the single by releasing a racing game on their website called “The Blame Game” (which would later be revealed as the title of the EP). annotations:
Stop saying, “It’s my bad”
 You’re acting like your deadbeat dad

Whoever the artist is talking to (most likely someone previously committed in a romantic manner to her) is avoidant in a passive manner and prefers to side step the situation by dismissively accepting little blame. The phrase “stop saying” indicates that the artist has already heard the following phrase “It’s my bad” so much that it has lost its original meaning.

The second half of this phrase is slightly ironic but embodies the point of the song. It shows manipulative people that their tactics are offensive and unnecessary. Here, the artist deliberately brings up a topic likely sensitive to her subject to guilt them into complying with her demands. This is a common tactic among players: to compare their lovers to annoying and detestable beings to over exaggerate the scope of their actions.
Who’s the girl in your story?

“Story” here could mean a social media story, a series of short videos or photos users can post. Notable social media sites Instagram and Snapchat utilize this functionality. The artist could be saying she saw he was hanging out with another girl on his story. Basically, he lied to the artist about having a girl that is “just a friend” – which we all know to mean they were hooking up.

Say you want me, actually, you want me
 Did you want a ribbon?
The artist is facetiously asking if the ghost wants to be rewarded for doing the bare minimum to keep up the relationship.

You’re not a ghost, I’m not afraid of you
 I started letting go

“Ghosting” is a slang term for when a person stops communicating with a friend or romantic interest, typically without warning. The artist is saying she’s caught on to their game and isn’t going to let it rule her. She’s “started letting go” and detaching herself before they could leave for good.

Beach Bunny has also used the imagery of “ghosts” on a track from their Pool Party EP named “Ghost.”

description.plain: The singer is in pain because of her recent breakup. She isn’t in physical pain, but wants painkillers anyway because of her emotional pain.

body.plain: The singer is in pain because of her recent breakup. She isn’t in physical pain, but wants painkillers anyway because of her emotional pain.

songs.full_title: Painkiller - Audiotree Live Version by Beach Bunny
songs.title: Painkiller - Audiotree Live Version

annotations:
Codependency is
 Hard to break when you
 Never make it easy
She realises that she and her partner won’t survive without each other but is wondering if this is intentional manipulation by her partner to stop Bunny from leaving.

You’re careful with your words
 But I’m pulling teeth

Although the person she is arguing with is being evasive and secretive “You’re careful with your words”, she is “pulling teeth” meaning she is pushing hard and getting some information out of him despite him resisting.

Reconstructive surgery
 Can’t fix my anxiety
The narrator is still insecure, even though she became a  “defect surgical project” in “Prom Queen”.

You’ve been such a jerk
 Since you left last week
Bunny’s lover left recently, likely due to a fight, but he’s not leaving her alone or trying to make amends.

And all of your apologies
 Are only empty calories

Empty calories refers to food that is high-calorie but has little nutritional value (junk food); the apologies are like empty calories in that they may seem good, but they are devoid of any real substance or value. They don’t fix anything, and they are just meaningless gestures.
Sometimes, sorry’s just another word you’re sayin’
Similar to the previous line, “all of your apologies are only empty calories,” she expresses how his apologies are effectively meaningless. They hold no value, and they are just empty gestures.

Every conversation puts me
 Back on medication
Every conversation with him is painful for her. Like the title of the song suggests, she needs a way to numb the pain she experiences every time she is with him.

After all this time
 I start asking why I’m staying
 Were you ever mine?
 Are we something that’s worth saving?
The relationship the narrator had with her former lover was one sided, as in she put more than what she got from it. Yet, she is still wondering if maybe it is still worth saving it.

Do I look like her?
 Does she talk like me?
 Been feeling insecure

It is implied here that the former lover of the narrator left her for another girl, like the one she compares herself to in “Prom Queen”, or alternatively, that the narrator is projecting her jealousy.

Take me to the hospital
 I need Paracetamol
 Tramadol, Ketamine
 I just need some pain relief
The narrator is not in physical pain, the pain she feels is emotional. Regardless she asks for various pain killers to relieve her of her heartbreak.

description.plain:
“Cloud 9” originally appeared on Beach Bunny’s 2020 album Honeymoon as the album’s third single. Following the song gaining more traction in 2021, Beach Bunny collaborated with Canadian indie pop duo Tegan and Sara to record a new version of the song.

While the song remains mostly similar to the original, the major difference is the lyrics in each chorus. The first chorus uses he/him pronouns as the original does; however, the second chorus uses she/her pronouns, while the final chorus uses they/them pronouns. Lili Trifilio’s goal with this version of the song was to make it more inclusive.

“Cloud 9” originally appeared on Beach Bunny’s 2020 album Honeymoon as the album’s third single. Following the song gaining more traction in 2021, Beach Bunny collaborated with Canadian indie pop duo Tegan and Sara to record a new version of the song.

While the song remains mostly similar to the original, the major difference is the lyrics in each chorus. The first chorus uses he/him pronouns as the original does; however, the second chorus uses she/her pronouns, while the final chorus uses they/them pronouns. Lili Trifilio’s goal with this version of the song was to make it more inclusive.

annotations:
But when she loves me, I feel like I’m floating
 When she calls me pretty, I feel like somebody
 Even when we fade eventually to nothing
 You will always be my favorite form of loving

Originally with only he/him pronouns, this new version of the song with Tegan and Sara highlights loving not only a person who uses he/him pronouns, but also a person who uses she/her and they/them pronouns – ultimately achieving an inclusive song that represents the LGBTQIA+ community.

description.plain:
“Oxygen” is the lead single from Beach Bunny’s sophomore album Emotional Creature, and was their first release of new music since their Blame Game EP nine months prior. The single also closely followed their appearance on a remix of MARINA’s “I Love You But I Love Me More” exactly one week earlier.

In a press release for the single, songwriter Lili Trifilio explained that the song is “about the perils of navigating romantic feelings, the joy that comes with allowing love to happen, and the act of letting go of the anxiety and our inner voices that make us feel undeserving of love”.

On October 10, 2021, the band began teasing a “new era” on social media with several posts featuring sci-fi imagery. After sharing a release date and pre-save link on October 22, the single’s title was officially announced on October 26 alongside a snippet of the song’s lyrics.

The single artwork showcases the band’s new sci-fi aesthetic, featuring an illustration of an unconscious Trifilio being carried by a purple alien reminiscent of the DC Comics character Doctor Manhattan. The artwork was hand-painted by Paul Mann.

song.title: Oxygen

On October 10, 2021, the band began teasing a “new era” on social media with several posts featuring sci-fi imagery. After sharing a release date and pre-save link on October 22, the single’s title was officially announced on October 26 alongside a snippet of the song’s lyrics.

The single artwork showcases the band’s new sci-fi aesthetic, featuring an illustration of an unconscious Trifilio being carried by a purple alien reminiscent of the DC Comics character Doctor Manhattan. The artwork was hand-painted by Paul Mann.

annotations: Suddenly, everything is easy
After falling in love, everything seems bright and simplified. The person makes you feel like you can conquer  anything, the love feels life-changing.

search_results.lyrics:

I accidentally self-impose

Maybe you're the boy from my dreams

description.plain:
Released October 31st, 2019, “Dream Boy” is the lead single from Beach Bunny’s first full-length album, Honeymoon, released four months later.

Despite the Halloween release date, “Dream Boy” is more of an ode to summer and young love in general rather than any specific crush or relationship. Instead, the lyrics pay homage to the both the magic of a fresh young love and the beauty of summer in the band’s hometown of Chicago, two concepts that go hand-in-hand for singer/songwriter Lili Trifilio.

song.embed_content: Read “Dream Boy” by Beach Bunny on Genius
song.title: Dream Boy

body.plain:
Released October 31st, 2019, “Dream Boy” is the lead single from Beach Bunny’s first full-length album, Honeymoon, released four months later.

Despite the Halloween release date, “Dream Boy” is more of an ode to summer and young love in general rather than any specific crush or relationship. Instead, the lyrics pay homage to the both the magic of a fresh young love and the beauty of summer in the band’s hometown of Chicago, two concepts that go hand-in-hand for singer/songwriter Lili Trifilio.

annotations:
Easy love is hard to find
 Blushing eyes, she replies, “You feel like summer”

Lili Trifilio is especially fond of summer. Living in her hometown of Chicago, a city in which summer is but a short reprieve from the bitter cold, she compares the season to the feeling “of a budding relationship – a hopeful, relieving, exciting feeling.”

In many ways, “Dream Boy” is one long metaphor for summer. Not only was the song written during summer, but it was, as Lili puts it, “written to resemble summer in some form.”  Just as she sings that “Easy love is hard to find,” summer in Chicago is, in its own way, hard to find among the majority of the cold, windy year. When it does arrive, it brings a carefree spirit, or easiness, with it.
All you gotta do is meet me after, meet me after midnight

Continuing the theme of young love and the powerful emotions that it holds, this line is told from the perspective of a young teenager whom everyone expects to be sleeping in their bed at this time of night or early morning. Singer/songwriter Lili Trifilio says it eloquently:

Two teenagers  hopelessly in love, sneaking out after dark…I remember the thrill of staying out late in the park with the neighborhood kids in high school – we were good kids but just the act of being awake  when the rest of the world was indoors and asleep always made us feel unstoppable. It didn’t matter what we were doing or who came out – it’s those memories I carry with me that remind me the most of young love and summer sweethearts which have shaped some of the lyrics in the song.

I’ll be under your window in the moonlight
 Oh, I tend to keep my heart locked watertight

Inspired by what singer Lili Trifilio calls “rom-coms from cheesy to nauseating, especially the ones where a boy is waiting outside a girls window with a boombox,” this line is about the magic of young love and how quickly that spell can penetrate the heart (even if that heart is “locked watertight”).

The image of a boy holding a boombox over his head while gazing upwards to her window has become a familiar trope synonymous with young love.

It all started with the 1989 film, Say Anything. The movie stars John Cusack who, in one of the most famous scenes in the genre of romantic comedy, stands outside the window of the girl he loves, with a boombox held high over his head, playing Peter Gabriel’s “In Your Eyes”.

search_results.lyrics:
April Lyrics[Verse 1]
April showers, rain starts falling
I wish that you would pick up when you know I'm calling
It's been another year
Wishing you were here
Sometimes, I just want somebody
Someone who reminds me that they'll always love me
Sick of counting tears
Wishing you were here

[Chorus]

But oftentimes, I just get forgotten, oh
[Verse 2]
Are you out there? I'm still here
I wish that when I said your name, you would appear
Sitting next to me
Now we're memories
Sometimes, I just want somebody
Someone who reminds me that they'll always love me
Sick of counting tears
Wishing you were here

[Chorus]
I wanna be everything you wanted
But oftentimes, I just get forgotten

[Bridge]
Are you out there somewhere?
What are you up to?
Have you changed your number?
I've been trying to call you
Since April and now it's October
I'm not overthinking
But I think about you a lot
And lately, I am just an afterthought

[Outro]
Where did you go?

song.embed_content: Read “April” by Beach Bunny on Genius
song.title: April

annotations:
Are you out there somewhere?
 What are you up to?
 Have you changed your number?
 I’ve been trying to call you
 Since April and now it’s October
 I’m not overthinking
 But I think about you a lot
 And lately, I am just an afterthought

The singer, Lili Trifilio, seems to be experiencing a common, though, frankly, douchy breakup tactic called “ghosting”. This is when a partner in a relationship cuts contact with the other very suddenly. This can leave people thinking they’re not good enough and can possibly even lead to unhealthy coping mechanisms.

This ties into the line “Have you changed your number?” because the singer is in denial that she’s being ghosted and is holding onto false hope. This, however, will eventually shatter, causing the singer to realize what is truly going on.

Sometimes, I just want somebody
 Someone who reminds me that they’ll always love me
 Sick of counting tears
 Wishing you were here

The singer has been hurt by past love and is not quite over them yet. Over a year after they’ve called it quits, she still seeks validation; something she used to get from her past lover. Ms. California, another track from the album talks about how her ex has found a perfect new girl. She wishes that she was like this girl, just so she could be with him again and feel beautiful again. She wishes that she was good enough for her ex, but it was never good enough for him, causing her to spiral and overthink it.

search_results.lyrics:
Entropy Lyrics[Verse 1]
I'll get over it if you let me breathe
From the skin 'cause my lungs tend to keep it within
And I'm indifferent if you don't care
But you do, so I fear, disappear when I'm scared

[Pre-Chorus]
And I can't release, but I can't hold in
All the smiles and grinning
Like life is just beginning
[Chorus]
'Cause somebody's gonna figure me out
It's what I am, it's what I was, it's what I wanna become
Yeah, somebody's gonna figure us out
And I hope they do 'cause I'm falling for you, whoa

[Verse 2]
You'll get over it in a few months
See the way that I blush when our lips start to touch
And I'm emotional thinking about
Why I had any doubts from the words pouring out, yeah

[Pre-Chorus]
I can't exhale, but I can't hide
The letters in my bedroom
The way my heart's in bloom

[Chorus]
'Cause somebody's gonna figure me out
It's what I am, it's what I was, it's what I wanna become
Yeah, somebody's gonna figure us out
And I hope they do 'cause I'm falling for you, whoa

[Bridge]
Running away through the rain makes your socks wet
Splitting your heart and your brain makes you feel
Uncertain if thoughts were the same even back then
I feel ashamed, feel ashamed, feel ashamed
Running away through the rain with you, darling
Makes me feel safe like you saved me from drowning
I'm not ashamed, not ashamed, not ashamed
I wanna kiss you when everyone's watching

description.plain:
Entropy is described as a slow descent or decline into chaos. Beach Bunny’s song describes a feeling or relationship that needs to be hidden but the feelings in question are too big or too loud to be. Possibly sapphic, and at the risk of ostracism, this song describes wanting the world to know you love someone, but the world wouldn’t be accepting.

It also delves into the contradictory emotions of this love,
“Somebody’s gonna figure us out- and I hope they do ‘cause I’m fallin’ for you.”
“I wanna kiss you when everyone’s watching,” while also worrying about being figured out.
